Goursat's theorem

Prove Goursat's theorem: If f ⁣:C→C\func{f}{\C}{\C}f:C→C is complex differentiable (and so continuous), then for every triangle △⊆C\triangle \subseteq \C△⊆C

∮∂△f(z) dz=0\oint_{\partial\triangle} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = 0∮∂△​f(z)dz=0

where the line integral is over the three sides of the triangle.
Solution.

Fix a triangle △\triangle△ with vertices {z1,z2,z3}\set{z_1, z_2, z_3}{z1​,z2​,z3​} oriented counter-clockwise. Suppose otherwise, so that there exists ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 such that

∣∮∂△f(z) dz∣≥ε>0.\abs{\oint_{\partial\triangle} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} \geq \epsilon > 0.∣∣​∮∂△​f(z)dz∣∣​≥ε>0.

Decompose △1≔△\triangle_1 \coloneqq \triangle△1​:=△ into four further triangles: △1(1),△1(2),△1(3),△1(4)\triangle_1^{\p{1}}, \triangle_1^{\p{2}}, \triangle_1^{\p{3}}, \triangle_1^{\p{4}}△1(1)​,△1(2)​,△1(3)​,△1(4)​ so that

△1(1)has vertices{z1,z1+z22,z1+z32}△1(2)has vertices{z1+z22,z2+z32,z1+z3z2}△1(3)has vertices{z1+z22,z2,z2+z32}△1(4)has vertices{z1+z32,z2+z32,z3},\begin{aligned} \triangle_1^{\p{1}} & \quad\text{has vertices}\quad \set{z_1, \frac{z_1 + z_2}{2}, \frac{z_1 + z_3}{2}} \\ \triangle_1^{\p{2}} & \quad\text{has vertices}\quad \set{\frac{z_1 + z_2}{2}, \frac{z_2 + z_3}{2}, \frac{z_1 + z_3}{z_2}} \\ \triangle_1^{\p{3}} & \quad\text{has vertices}\quad \set{\frac{z_1 + z_2}{2}, z_2, \frac{z_2 + z_3}{2}} \\ \triangle_1^{\p{4}} & \quad\text{has vertices}\quad \set{\frac{z_1 + z_3}{2}, \frac{z_2 + z_3}{2}, z_3}, \end{aligned}△1(1)​△1(2)​△1(3)​△1(4)​​has vertices{z1​,2z1​+z2​​,2z1​+z3​​}has vertices{2z1​+z2​​,2z2​+z3​​,z2​z1​+z3​​}has vertices{2z1​+z2​​,z2​,2z2​+z3​​}has vertices{2z1​+z3​​,2z2​+z3​​,z3​},​

which have disjoint interiors and oriented counter-clockwise. By cancellation,

ε≤∣∫∂△1f(z) dz∣=∣∑j=14∫∂△1(j)f(z) dz∣≤∑j=14∣∫∂△1(j)f(z) dz∣,\begin{aligned} \epsilon &\leq \abs{\int_{\partial\triangle_1} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} \\ &= \abs{\sum_{j=1}^4 \int_{\partial\triangle_1^{\p{j}}} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} \\ &\leq \sum_{j=1}^4 \abs{\int_{\partial\triangle_1^{\p{j}}} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}}, \end{aligned}ε​≤∣∣​∫∂△1​​f(z)dz∣∣​=∣∣​j=1∑4​∫∂△1(j)​​f(z)dz∣∣​≤j=1∑4​∣∣​∫∂△1(j)​​f(z)dz∣∣​,​

by the triangle inequality. Thus, there exists j0j_0j0​ so that ∣∫∂△1(j0)f(z) dz∣≥ε4\abs{\int_{\partial\triangle_1^{\p{j_0}}} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} \geq \frac{\epsilon}{4}∣∣​∫∂△1(j0​)​​f(z)dz∣∣​≥4ε​ or else the triangle inequality implies

ε≤∑j=14∣∫∂△1(j)f(z) dz∣<∑j=14ε4=ε,\epsilon \leq \sum_{j=1}^4 \abs{\int_{\partial\triangle_1^{\p{j}}} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} < \sum_{j=1}^4 \frac{\epsilon}{4} = \epsilon,ε≤j=1∑4​∣∣​∫∂△1(j)​​f(z)dz∣∣​<j=1∑4​4ε​=ε,

which is impossible. Set △2=△1(j0)\triangle_2 = \triangle_1^{\p{j_0}}△2​=△1(j0​)​. By induction (e.g., by replacing △\triangle△ above with △n\triangle_n△n​), we get a sequence of triangles {△n}n\set{\triangle_n}_n{△n​}n​ such that △n⊇△n+1\triangle_n \supseteq \triangle_{n+1}△n​⊇△n+1​ and ∣∫∂△nf(z) dz∣≥ε4n−1\abs{\int_{\partial\triangle_n} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} \geq \frac{\epsilon}{4^{n-1}}∣∣​∫∂△n​​f(z)dz∣∣​≥4n−1ε​. Notice also that diam⁡△n=diam⁡△12n−1→0\diam{\triangle_n} = \frac{\diam{\triangle_1}}{2^{n-1}} \to 0diam△n​=2n−1diam△1​​→0 as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞, so by completeness of C\CC,

⋂n=1∞△1={z∗}.\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty \triangle_1 = \set{z^*}.n=1⋂∞​△1​={z∗}.

Since fff is complex differentiable, f′(z∗)f'\p{z^*}f′(z∗) exists and if we set h(z)=f(z)−f(z∗)z−z∗−f′(z∗)h\p{z} = \frac{f\p{z} - f\p{z^*}}{z - z^*} - f'\p{z^*}h(z)=z−z∗f(z)−f(z∗)​−f′(z∗), then h(z)→0h\p{z} \to 0h(z)→0 as z→z∗z \to z^*z→z∗ and

f(z)=f(z∗)+f′(z∗)(z−z∗)+h(z)(z−z∗).f\p{z} = f\p{z^*} + f'\p{z^*}\p{z - z^*} + h\p{z}\p{z - z^*}.f(z)=f(z∗)+f′(z∗)(z−z∗)+h(z)(z−z∗).

Moreover, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 so that ∣h(z)∣<η\abs{h\p{z}} < \eta∣h(z)∣<η, so because diam⁡△n→0\diam\triangle_n \to 0diam△n​→0, there exists n≥1n \geq 1n≥1 such that △n⊆B(z∗,δ)\triangle_n \subseteq B\p{z^*, \delta}△n​⊆B(z∗,δ). Observe that by the fundamental theorem of calculus, ∫γaz+b dz=0\int_\gamma az + b \,\diff{z} = 0∫γ​az+bdz=0 for any closed curve γ\gammaγ. Hence,

ε4n−1≤∣∫∂△nf(z) dz∣=∣∫∂△nf(z∗)+f′(z∗)(z−z∗)+h(z)(z−z∗) dz∣=∣∫∂△nh(z)(z−z∗) dz∣≤η∫∂△nsup⁡z∈∂△n∣z−z∗∣ d∣z∣≤η(diam⁡△n)2≤η(diam⁡△1)24n−1  ⟹  ε≤η(diam⁡△1)2.\begin{aligned} \frac{\epsilon}{4^{n-1}} &\leq \abs{\int_{\partial\triangle_n} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} \\ &= \abs{\int_{\partial\triangle_n} f\p{z^*} + f'\p{z^*}\p{z - z^*} + h\p{z}\p{z - z^*} \,\diff{z}} \\ &= \abs{\int_{\partial\triangle_n} h\p{z}\p{z - z^*} \,\diff{z}} \\ &\leq \eta \int_{\partial\triangle_n} \sup_{z \in \partial\triangle_n} \abs{z - z^*} \,\diff\abs{z} \\ &\leq \eta \p{\diam\triangle_n}^2 \\ &\leq \frac{\eta\p{\diam{\triangle_1}}^2}{4^{n-1}} \\ \implies \epsilon &\leq \eta\p{\diam{\triangle_1}}^2. \end{aligned}4n−1ε​⟹ε​≤∣∣​∫∂△n​​f(z)dz∣∣​=∣∣​∫∂△n​​f(z∗)+f′(z∗)(z−z∗)+h(z)(z−z∗)dz∣∣​=∣∣​∫∂△n​​h(z)(z−z∗)dz∣∣​≤η∫∂△n​​z∈∂△n​sup​∣z−z∗∣d∣z∣≤η(diam△n​)2≤4n−1η(diam△1​)2​≤η(diam△1​)2.​

Letting η→0\eta \to 0η→0, however, we see that ε=0\epsilon = 0ε=0, which is impossible. Thus, ε\epsilonε must have been 000 to begin with, which completes the proof.
